Effectiveness of the multi-scale 3D convolution module.
To validate the effectiveness of this module, we conducted four sets of experiments. Firstly, we replaced the multi-scale (MS) 3D convolution layers with kernel size r4Ã—rÃ—3Ã—1Ã—1ğ‘Ÿ4ğ‘Ÿ311\frac{r}{4}\times r\times 3\times 1\times 1divide start_ARG italic_r end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG Ã— italic_r Ã— 3 Ã— 1 Ã— 1 shown in Fig.Â 2(c) with a single 3D convolution layer with kernel size rÃ—rÃ—3Ã—1Ã—1ğ‘Ÿğ‘Ÿ311r\times r\times 3\times 1\times 1italic_r Ã— italic_r Ã— 3 Ã— 1 Ã— 1. Secondly, we increased the kernel size along the depth dimension from 3333 to 5555. Table.Â 4 shows that the MS design significantly enhances performance, benefiting from the expansion of the modelâ€™s local receptive field.

Effectiveness of the scanning strategy.
Table.Â 4 shows that scanning from depth-width planes surpasses both volume flattening and scanning from height-width planes, primarily due to its more effective capture of depth-level and 3D structural information. Furthermore, ensemble scanning across all three planes (height-width, depth-width, and depth-height) further boosts performance

Effectiveness of the low rank rğ‘Ÿritalic_r. As shown in Table.Â 4, our algorithm maintains a consistent performance across different values of rğ‘Ÿritalic_r, presenting strong robustness without significant fluctuations in performance.
